awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Global Algorithm for Quadratic Nonconvex AC-OPF Based on Successive Linear Optimization and Convex Relaxation
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-convex programming involves optimization problems where either the objective function or constraint set is a non-convex function. These kinds of problems arise in a broad range of applications in engineering systems. Despite the substantial literature on convex and non-convex quadratic programming (general classes of optimization problems), most available optimization techniques are either not scalable or work efficiently only for convex quadratic programming and do not provide adequate results for non-convex quadratic programming. This project focuses on fundamental research on an integrated approach which the research team expects will lead to powerful solution methods for classes of non-convex programming problems. The new approach will be applicable for non-convex problems arising in many areas, such as power and energy systems, transportation, and communications. The project will involve students from underrepresented groups and will positively impact engineering education.

The general difficulty of power and energy optimization problems has a direct impact on power and energy systems management. This is one of the most fundamental concerns that must be dealt with in electrical power system management. The primary objective of this project is to address the difficulty associated with problem non-convexity by developing high-performance optimization techniques that apply to a broad set of nonlinear energy problems, particularly the Optimal Power Flow (OPF) problem. There is a critical and urgent need for developing smart and robust OPF solvers. The conventional options currently available for DC-OPF are quite limited. The research will fundamentally address AC Optimal Power Flow (AC-OPF) with active and reactive quadratically constrained quadratic programming optimization problems of a form that arises in operation and planning applications of the power system. Besides being non-convex, these problems are identified to be NP-hard. The proposed solution method is based on several basic and powerful optimization techniques in convex optimization theory such as linearized approximation techniques, linear and global search procedures, bi-linear and convex relaxation, and alternate direction methods. Also, new schemes and theories must be introduced to establish the convergence of the algorithm and guarantee the global optimality of the solution results. The research team devised a new successive linear optimization based branch and bound (SLOBB) method based on deploying principles of the classical linear approximation, improved convex relaxation, and the branch-and-bound technique to find the global optimal solution of the AC-OPF problem. Since the linear programming and convex solvers are robust and fast, and also the power systems community is already familiar with linear and convex programs for OPF, the algorithm that will be developed will be beneficial and user-friendly for the AC-OPF problem. We will also pursue theoretical investigations to examine the performance of the proposed algorithm and analyze its efficiency on existing test bed systems and synthetic data sets. The developed models and methodologies will be executed in real-world practical power grids.

Project Outcomes Report

Overview

This project aimed to tackle the complex problem of optimizing power flow in electrical grids, known as the Alternating Current Optimal Power Flow (ACOPF) problem. By formulating this problem as a Linear Constrained Quadratic Program (LCQP), we developed innovative algorithms to find globally optimal solutions efficiently. Our work has significant implications for the stability and efficiency of modern power systems, especially with the increasing integration of renewable energy sources.

Intellectual Merit

The ACOPF problem is known for its complexity and non-convex nature, making it a challenging task for researchers and engineers. Our project addressed this by developing two novel algorithms: Feasible Successive Linear Programming (FSLP) and Feasible Branch-and-Bound (FBB). These algorithms leverage advanced optimization techniques, including convex relaxation, initialization, and branch-and-bound strategies, to provide robust solutions to the ACOPF problem.

Key outcomes of our work include:

  1. Algorithm Development: We created the FSLP and FBB algorithms to solve the ACOPF problem efficiently. These algorithms reduce computational complexity, making it feasible to handle large-scale power systems.
  2. Complexity Bound Establishment: The complexity bound of our algorithms was established, ensuring they are scalable and effective even for large problem sizes.
  3. Validation and Performance: Our algorithms were tested against standard IEEE benchmark systems, demonstrating their robustness and efficiency in finding global optimal solutions.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of our project extend beyond the immediate field of power systems optimization. Our findings have implications for various disciplines, including computer science, applied mathematics, renewable energy, and engineering education.

  1. Enhancing Educational Experiences: We developed new graduate courses based on our research findings:

    • Modern Optimization for Energy and Complex Engineering Systems: This course integrates our advanced optimization techniques, providing students with hands-on experience in solving real-world energy system problems.
    • Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Applications: Focused on the application of AI and ML in engineering, this course uses case studies from our project to teach students about cutting-edge technologies.

  2. Human Resource Development: Our project provided significant training opportunities for students and researchers. Graduate students participated in hands-on research projects, gaining invaluable experience in advanced optimization and computational techniques. Workshops and seminars further disseminated our findings, enhancing the skills of faculty and professionals in the field.

  3. Infrastructure Improvement: The project led to upgrades in computational laboratories and the establishment of dedicated optimization labs. These facilities now support a wide range of research and educational activities, benefiting future projects and students.

  4. Sustainability and Renewable Energy: By optimizing power flow in grids with high renewable energy penetration, our work contributes to the development of sustainable energy systems. The techniques we developed help manage the variability and uncertainty associated with renewable sources, ensuring grid stability and efficiency.

Conclusion

In summary, this project has significantly advanced the field of power systems optimization through the development of innovative algorithms and methodologies. The intellectual merit of our work lies in solving a long-standing complex problem, while the broader impacts enhance education, infrastructure, and the integration of renewable energy. Our findings not only improve the stability and efficiency of modern power systems but also prepare the next generation of engineers and researchers to tackle future challenges in this dynamic field.
